title: CTRL0000062442 - Transcribed Interview of William Bock IV, (April 15, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 9:49 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
We'll go on the record at 9:49 a.m.
This is a deposition of William Bock, IV, conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
Mr. Bock, please state your full name and spell your last name for the record.
My name is William Bock, IV, and my last name is spelled B-o-c-k.
And would you please raise your right hand
to be sworn by the court reporter.
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
So this will be a staff-led deposition, and members, of course, may choose to ask
I don't see any on the Webex right now.
, investigative counsel, and on the Webex today with me
We will follow the House deposition rules that we've provided to your counsel
name for the record and to please state the names of anyone else who might be in the
room for the record as well.
Under the House deposition rules, you are permitted to have an attorney
And, Mr. Bock, at this time, I'm going to ask your counsel to please state his
My name is John Burlingame with Squire Patton Boggs
With me in the room are two other attorneys for
Mr. Bock, and my co-counsel, first, Dan Delnero, D-e-1-n-e-r-o, and also with me here is
Thank you very much, Mr. Burlingame.
Under the House deposition rules, neither committee members nor staff may
discuss the substance of testimony you provide today unless the committee approves
before we begin, I'd like to just describe a few ground rules.
You and your attorney will have an opportunity to review the transcript.
There's an official reporter transcribing the record of this deposition.
reporter is also joining us by Webex.
make sure to wait until each question I have asked is completed before you begin your
answer, and I will -- myself a n d - and whoever else who will join will do the same and
try to wait for your answer to finish before we ask our next question.
have a really hard time hearing voices overlapping, especially over Webex.
Hey,., I'm sorry, let me interrupt.
Let's take a quick recess in place and figure this out.
me hooked up to the video system in the room, so Dan is going to click a button.
So just because of the limits of technology, please
Let's -- yeah, we can go off the record.
Let's go back on the record at 9:55.
nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head, so it is important that you answer each
question with an audible, verbal response.
record, there may be times where I spell a name or a word that we are using, or that I ask
And for the benefit of the reporter and the
And we ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If the question is not clear, which is almost certain to happen, please just ask for
If you do not know the answer, please simply say so.
And logistically, please let us know if you need any breaks for comfort, or if you
would like to discuss something with Mr. Burlingame or you other attorneys privately,
and we are happy to accommodate.
Throughout the deposition, we will be directing your attention to exhibits, which
will be displayed on the screen, and when we refer you to a document, you can take time
to familiarize yourself with it before we discuss.
So I'm going to pull up exhibit 1 and we'll see how this is working.
Mr. Bock, can you see exhibit 1?
I can -- is there -- I can -- it's sort of far away.
I can see, you know, "subpoena" at the top of the --
I'm putting the subpoena in front of him as well,
Mr. Bock, do you recognize that as the subpoena and
accompanying documents that the select committee issued to you?
Yeah, you can see it for purposes and I can pull out the exhibit.
I -- I recognize this as the subpoena that I received.
So under the subpoena's rules, you may only refuse to
answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by the select committee.
refuse answer a question based on privilege, staff may either proceed with the
deposition, or seek a ruling from the chairman on the objection.
overrules such an objection, you are required to answer the question.

asking for their opinion about executive privilege.
I did that with a previous witness,
actually called White House counsel this time around, requested a letter from the

White House counsel, which I know you have as well.
In which counsel states that President Biden accordingly has decided
not to assert executive privilege as to Mr. Back's testimony regarding the subjects that
you discussed or any documents he may possess that bear on them?
that the witness has seen as well.
So at this time, Mr. Burlingame, I'd ask that you please place on the record any
Yes, that is the letter I received from White House counsel and
objections you might have or any opening remarks that you'd wish to make.
My only opening remark is this
witness will be testifying, I don't expect to assert any privileges, but obviously his

And, Mr. Bock, I also want to remind you -- and we do this for all witnesses -- that
it is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
is under oath, providing false information could result in criminal penalties to include for
So we'll start out with just some background questions.
And where are you currently living?
I currently live in Ann Arbor, Michigan.
And what are you doing there?
Congratulate him after the end of his first year.
I've got a few more weeks to go.
Did you work in President Trump's administration?
What was your role or roles?
So I started work at the White House as a research associate in the Office of
Presidential Personnel, and then I moved to the Office of Speechwriting and worked as a
researcher and executive assistant in the Office of Speechwriting.
And I think I left the
administration with a different title, director of research for the Office of Speechwriting.
Do you think that last title is the one that you held from November 2020 to
I believe that it was in December of 2020 that my title changed from
I would -- I don't exactly recall the date that that
Was there a significant change in your role, though, with the change in title
There was not a -- I wouldn't call it a significant change.
of the same things that I had been doing as a researcher, yeah.
What additional responsibilities did you have?
I was asked to help with a presidential proclamation as director of research
and -- and also to help with a particular report concerning the 1776 commission that the
In the time period we're primarily concerned with, November 2020 to
January 2021, who did you report to?
I reported to, well, really all of the speechwriters in the office.
primarily reported to Patrick MacDonnell, who was the former director of research in the
of the speechwriters in the office.
And then I also worked -- I would say I worked closely with all
Including Vincent -- Vincent Haley and Ross Worthington?
Did you ever work directly with Stephen Miller?
I -- I don't believe I worked directly with Stephen Miller.
report to Ross and Vince, who may have interacted with Stephen Miller, but I was mainly
working with Patrick and the other speechwriters.
I supervised a group of interns at that time.
Did you supervise anybody during that time?
And can you just give me a quick rundown of your
So as the researcher, I would provide research to support and inform

as they were drafting presidential remarks.
proclamation and doing some other research just for senior administration officials like
I would say that was my primary
I also helped with, as I mentioned, you know, drafting a presidential

Yeah, the standard process would be we would hear about a

about what the administration had done to effectuate criminal justice reform, what

statements already made by the administration and sources coming out of the

I would say that it wasn't like we looked at one particular place first.
sort of we'd provide a research product that had all of those elements where we had, you
know, past statements as well as additional research that we had done, you know, if the
event was on criminal justice reform just, you know, statistics and policy-related
information that the writers had requested.
And as a grad student, you are learning this well.
use like social science databases, legal databases like, you know, HeinOnline, that kind of

It was both open source, as well as legal databases.
if particular agencies, you know, had given us our office information, that would, in some

databases, it was also collecting the internal information that we had.
So it was -- it was open source, it was looking at scholarly
Did you also have a fact-checking role as part of your
And can you describe the process generally for fact-checking for me?
So we would -- I would receive a set of presidential remarks.
would come to me, and I would work to try and find support for the particular statements
that were made in the remarks.
between me and the writers, as well as other White House components who would also
be reviewing the remarks, as we were all trying to work to ensure the accuracy of the
that there was support that was being relied on in the particular statements that made
their way into the draft of the President's remarks.
And this was -- this was a collaborative process
And it was mainly collecting information to demonstrate
Then what happened if yourself or another researcher who's doing
fact checking found something that you could not verify?
We would usually put a comment to the side, like when we're -- we receive
the text of the remarks, we would, you know, just put a comment in the Word document
noting that we did not have -- we did not believe, you know, in our personal opinion, that
we could find sources supporting that.
And so -- so in the vast majority of instances, it was leaving the comments that we
would then later discuss with the writer, sometimes as well it was also just a verbal
discussion that we had with the writer that -- you know, where I would go ask like where
exactly, you know, did the information that we're relying on for this statement come
And were your statements about being unable to verify certain
facts determinative about whether that claim would make it into the final speech?
I don't know if I can give you a, like a categorical statement on that.
would say that, you know, every time that, you know, I would leave a fact check with Ross
and Vince, they would always come to me -- that -- always that I can remember would
come to me and try and work through whatever suggestions or comments I had left for
was sent to other White House components would look like.
Ultimately, it was the decision of the writers themselves as to what the draft that

made their way into draft speeches that the President saw?
To the best of my recollection, I -- I don't recall particular instances
It certainly could've, but I don't recall.
And I know earlier you mentioned that you never

direct contact with him about draft speeches?
I don't recall a particular instance.
You know, sometimes, I believe, he

end where it's like, Okay, you know, we've put out this statement, we've done our due
